docs.lead_paragraph: Six of 32 young male workers who went to a hospital with breathing problems died, and 16 others had disabling lung damage from breathing the fine sand, the study found.

headline.seo: Silicosis From Work on Blue Jeans Killed Workers, Study Says
headline.main: Turkey: Sandblasting Jeans for ‘Distressed’ Look Proved Harmful for Textile Workers
headline.print_headline: Turkey: Sandblasting Jeans for ‘Distressed’ Look Proved Harmful to Textile Workers

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Chest finds sandblasting new blue jeans to make them look 'distressed' caused number of young Turkish textile workers to die of lung deterioration before practice was outlawed.
docs.snippet: Six of 32 young male workers who went to a hospital with breathing problems died, and 16 others had disabling lung damage from breathing the fine sand, the study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: Steve Jobs’s decision to delay an operation to remove a tumor may not have been as ill considered as it seems at first blush.

headline.seo: Hindsight Is Kind to Steve Jobs’s Decision to Delay Surgery
headline.main: A Tumor Is No Clearer in Hindsight
headline.print_headline: A Tumor Is No Clearer In Hindsight

docs.abstract: Steve Job's decision to delay an operation to remove tumor and pursue alternative cancer remedies may not have been as ill-considered as many contend; if cancer had produced micrometasteses, operation would not have saved his life; Jobs consulted with number of physicians and considered several options before opting out of surgery.
docs.snippet: Steve Jobs’s decision to delay an operation to remove a tumor may not have been as ill considered as it seems at first blush.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers point to differences in neck strength and musculature, and the fact that safety devices have been designed largely for male drivers.

headline.seo: Women at Greater Risk of Injury in Car Crashes, Study Finds
headline.main: Safety: Car Crashes Pose Greater Risk for Women
headline.print_headline: Safety: Car Crashes Pose Greater Risk for Women

docs.abstract: Report published online in The American Journal of Public Health by researchers at the University of Virginia finds women driving cars are much more likely than male drivers to be seriously injured in a crash.
docs.snippet: Researchers point to differences in neck strength and musculature, and the fact that safety devices have been designed largely for male drivers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Subjects in a large new study who had trouble falling asleep had a 45 percent increased relative risk of heart attack.

headline.seo: Chronic Insomnia Raises Heart Attack Threat, Study Says
headline.main: Risks: Chronic Insomnia Raises Threat to Heart
headline.print_headline: Risks: Chronic Insomnia Raises Threat to Heart

docs.abstract: Study published online in journal Circulation finds chronic insomnia may increase the risk of heart attack; lead author of study is Lars E Laugsand of the Norwegian University of Science and Technology.
docs.snippet: Subjects in a large new study who had trouble falling asleep had a 45 percent increased relative risk of heart attack.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ideal physician surely possesses both competence and compassion. Will our quest to eradicate the coldhearted doctor be another fad with consequences we may regret?

headline.seo: The Downside of Doctors Who Feel Your Pain
headline.main: The Downside of Doctors Who Feel Your Pain
headline.print_headline: Downside Of Doctors Who Feel Your Pain

docs.abstract: Essay by Dr Lisa Rosenbaum contends medical fad for developing strong interpersonal skills in doctors, and weeding out medical students without them, may have unforeseen consequences.
docs.snippet: The ideal physician surely possesses both competence and compassion. Will our quest to eradicate the coldhearted doctor be another fad with consequences we may regret?

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers report that a combination of fatty acids expands the heart cells of a well-fed snake, a finding that holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.

headline.seo: Python Digestion Study Holds Promise for Human Heart Health
headline.main: Snakes’ Feat May Inspire Heart Drugs
headline.print_headline: Snakes’ Feat May Inspire Heart Drugs

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Science finds that a combination of fatty acids allows heart cells of a well-fed python to expand while snake digests its prey; study, conducted by scientists at the University of Colorado, holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.
docs.snippet: Researchers report that a combination of fatty acids expands the heart cells of a well-fed snake, a finding that holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.

byline.contributor: Maria Elkin contributed reporting from Washington.
